After reaching the Caribbean islands, he continued to explore the coasts of South and Central America, claiming them for Spain. Columbus made three more voyages to the Americas, sponsored by the Catholic Monarchs, and during his second voyage, he founded the settlement of La Isabela on the island of Hispaniola. However, his treatment of the indigenous Taíno people was brutal, and he ordered his men to enslave them and extract gold and other resources from their land. Columbus' legacy is a subject of debate, with some viewing him as a hero and others as a villain.
